TOMS is a company that is young and entrepreneurial. The people here are collaborative and genuinely care about each other and the company. The environment is relaxed and playful - you can typically find dogs to play with or a game of ping pong going on. Company events ("TOMS Holidays") are held as sacred and are held each year, without fail. TOMS ensures that we have a lot of opportunities to connect and build relationships as a company.

I'm going to disagree with a lot of the other posts I've read on this site. I see that a great deal of posts complain about internal growth/career opportunities. From what I see at TOMS, employees feel that after having been with the company for a few years (often it was their first job out of college) that they are entitled to a promotion, even if they sincerely lack the skills/abilities for that next-level role. They think it's a given because they are passionate about the brand. Often managers are in the position to have to look externally because the skill set just doesn't exist in-house. We have a lot of passionate people who think they've got the skill set, but the reality is, they just don't.

Advice to all current TOMS employees: have an opinion about your career. Know what you want to do and go after it. Stop waiting for your manager (or HR) to hand it to you. The opportunities are there -- you just have to go and grab them.

In spite of its maturity there are still aspects of the company that are start-up like. This includes growth spurts to flux in head count, management, and changes to house rules. Regardless, the growth is understandable and if you can accept that and roll with the punches then its all good.

From my experience, this was not a good place for women to work. There are a lot of publicly treasured golden boys who walk on water. Regardless of the many "stats" that may be shared with the employees that appear to show how edX is a great place for all who work there, what you cannot quantify is how the women are treated by male leadership and by their peers, when nobody is watching. That cannot be put into a graph, because nobody actually collected that data. You get what you measure. 

Being "a great place to work for women" is more than just offering a certain amount of maternity leave that is better than the average; that is a fancy trick to distract you from the real issues. How are the men treating the women when there aren't any witnesses? I didn't see this question on the engagement survey, and even if it were, nobody did anything with that engagement survey data anyway, did they? The "First Rule of Data Collection" should be "Only collect data if you're really going to use it".

Things took a turn for the worse after two very down-to-earth senior leaders departed the company. It changed the tenor of the entire operation.  I experienced and witnessed the biases towards the men here, and my female coworkers and I knew we would get nowhere sharing this with any remaining leadership. There are other companies where you might actually have a fair shot as a woman; this is not the place.

• High turnover in Management due to upper management. 
• Upper Management / Head Office staff are unbelievably awful to deal with and make everything difficult 
• Store Managers are unable to make decisions on their own. If you want to be a real manager - this is not the place for you. 
• You are to adhere to rules made in the 1990’s. If you dare to even suggest the slightest change, for an actual example “I have years worth of customer records on paper, just laying around - could I please have a small box to file them in? Possibly this $6 one from Officeworks?” You are hit with absolutely outrageous responses. The request must be put through and approved by Retail Ops. Who then send your request to your RBM, and also the Head of Retail Ops, and then they ask you … in a email including everyone they can think of, why? What size is the box? Where do you plan to put this box? Please send a photo of where you are thinking of putting this box. As if you wouldn’t know to store an A4 size $6 box in a cupboard or drawer. This went back and forth for 6 weeks before a phone conversation had to be had about it. 
That’s not an exaggeration. That’s a factual example. 
• Every part of your management style and previous skills are ignored. Aēsop wants you to conform. It’s their way or the highway. No personal belongings. Not your own drink bottle - you must only drink from Aēsop cups (recycled candle holders). No pens to be used unless they are black. No individually wrapped foods (even if it’s your own from home) The list is endless 
• There is close to zero chance of making your budget / bonus. There is no incentive to staff to work towards their targets. 
• You are isolated. Deliberately. All of your communication comes from your RBM. They limit your interactions with other managers. Very deliberately. 
• You are subjected to endless training sessions and visits from Trainers, who understandably must justify their wages, however, you and your staff are treated like Kindergarten students who are learning to behave for the first time. 
• Every single thing happening in the business is gate-kept. Like it’s going to change the world. 
• You do a mini stocktake once a week, if you get it wrong - that’s totally fine. You just give a reason or state “idk why” and that’s acceptable. If you get it right - exactly right more than 1 week in a row - someone will be sent out to count on your behalf. No one can ever be right.
* HR are unhelpful and will avoid as much as they can. When an incident arises, they will refer you to the EAP and leave you with it. An example, whilst being stalked and harassed by a physically abusive staff member, involving the police - not one time was support given from any upper management or HR. The staff member in question was put on 2 months of paid leave whilst the victims were made to make 4 statements and were constantly required to be on call, outside of their working hours. 
* Getting any assistance outside of Upper Management’s rigid business hours of 8.30-5 Monday to Friday is impossible. 
* The buildings are all in dire need of maintenance. Leaking taps, leaking sinks, leaking air conditioners. Mould is rampant through the buildings. Insects are everywhere. Some stores don’t even have working air conditioning and are extremely hot or freezing cold. The smells are repugnant and you’re told to cover it up with oil burners, candles and incense. 
* Work Health and Safety is only new to the companies policies and procedures. As long as it looks good, no one in Aēsop cares. Safework NSW have become involved but no one is allowed to talk to anyone about it. 
None of this is an exaggeration. All of this is factual. I could list many, many more things. I would not return to this company for $1million per day. I have not experienced anything like this place in my entire life. Don’t fall for it. They make it sound great. It’s not. Not in Sydney. Ask about the turnover, and dig deeper. Contact former staff members on LnkdIn. Ask them. Don’t do this to yourself, your family or your career.

There are clear favorites in every department or business segments. I've seen people get promoted every year or at least 1 promotion every two years. Others are overlooked, told they need to do more, but not given more work or opportunities to shine. So, basically how well can you manage up? How many meetings can you go to and show your face, put yourself out there, get known, build alliances with others so when they have their year end review, people say great things about you. The performance review is somewhat of a joke. I'm glad it is no longer discretionary and most of it is based on EBITDA. The company is running slim and there are still going to be some more layoffs. I still gave this company 3 stars because I for the most part enjoyed my time at TOMS. Every place is political, I just don't think you have to be an a%$ kisser to get ahead at ALL companies. Titles don't mean much just dictates your pay. A lot of top heavy positions, but not enough senior level employees to put in the hard work. Product is not that great, but they've put a lot of money on future seasons so maybe that will change. Lastly, at the end of the day, TOMS is a for profit business. They try to portray that they are contributing so much to help children, but they could easily just donate the money to those communities. People need food and water, paved roads, better infrastructure, not a pair of shoes which are the cheapest kind they purchase. It's the classic, give a man a fish, but don't teach him to be a fisherman. Change the give model to donate real resources and not shoes because it's 2017, A LOT of companies give back as part of their business model now!

Lovely, aromatic products with no "fluff" ingredients with few exceptions (the reformulation, Parsley Seed Intense Serum, is absolutely stellar). Trainings intended to build a consultant's own style of presenting without being didactic, instead encouraging you to blend and try products yourself and share them to clients as you would a friend hosted in your home. For instance, the price range is on the lower end of luxury cosmetics, and yet they have been able to achieve a B Corp certification, collaborate with an Indigenous-run sandalwood farm for sourcing, support the growth of new disruptors within the industry with a venture fund, and reduce waste significantly by, among other things, using Australian recyclable waste with a splash of brown dye for their signature Hand Wash bottles. Aesthetics and ingredients will leave you inspired when you finish your shift. *The* ideal student job, I would say, down to the supportive salary, interesting and diverse employees and development of soft skills (through projects that you set for yourself with your manager). Tip for interviews: do not be afraid to talk about your own passion projects!

Work-life balance is a hard thing to find. The only constant is change - we're growing really fast so the organization keeps changing, with people moving around and a lot of new folks coming on board all the time. When so much is changing, it can be hard to stay focused on your own priorities.

- Best culture in the valley. Everyone I've met here has been incredibly friendly, humble, super smart, and mission oriented. Having worked at many places in the Valley, including FANG, with both brogrammers and antisocial engineers, one cannot take that for granted. I am good friends with many of my coworkers, we are often found chatting with each other in the kitchen about everything under the sun, and many people hang out with each other after hours. It feels like a family.

- high impact. As an individual contributor you are working on major features from day one, and I have a lot of freedom to take ownership of the spec.

- Great work-life balance. You're trusted to get your work done and your managers support you and care about you as a person, not just an employee. Flexible WFH Wednesdays. As an engineer, if we need to modify timelines managers are generally understanding and will back you up instead of pressuring you.

- great growth potential. the new CEO is pushing the company in a profitable direction with online degrees, there's a lot of momentum with both university and industry partnerships, and we are in great financial shape heading into the new year. I'm excited for the future growth of the company.
Even though I was Canadian, I was super welcomed! So grateful for the amazing staff.

Coursera’s strong financial position with no debt (close to $1B in assets) and executives with 8-figure salaries (plus bonus) were given a substantial amount of RSU’s without vesting cliffs granted in Oct and received in Nov shortly after the layoff. Other prominent organizations with layoffs considered the impact to those laid-off and accelerated the grants and waived vesting cliffs. For a B corp company which prides itself on doing the right thing and investing in its people, senior leadership quickly forgot that philosophy when it came to receiving RSUs. Before accepting the offer ask these questions from the Sales Head:
1. How many sellers stay in Coursera even after 1 year? 
You may be surprised to learn that most of them leave within 4-6 quarters because they realise that that territory they have has been allocated does not allow them to even come close to quota

There has been an increasing, egregious lack of consideration for employees. This ongoing deterioration has only accelerated and intensified under new corporate direction. In spite of diversionary tactics such as empathy trainings and wholesome, long-term goals for Kiehl's, corporate actions toward employees have demonstrated the antithesis of such values and practices. Instead of being forthcoming and transparent, corporate has kept employees in the dark about their futures in the company; instead of honesty, we have gotten euphemisms - "service-focused scheduling models" and unmentionable inanities about selling techniques, composed with the inclusion of emojis. Such flimsily yet thickly veiled proceedings are not positive for anyone involved, and to dress them up in any other way is disingenuous, insulting, and in bad faith. We deserve respect. A company that is solely profit-driven with little regard for the livelihoods of its employees is one of which I cannot be a part. What is happening now will only foster an adversarial relationship between a company and its employees; both will suffer.
* Great for learning * Coursera for life * Friendly team * Great pay & benefits * Unlimited PTO

Recent hires haven been extremely disappointing. Managerial positions last less than 2 years at a minimum which resulted in frequent changes of business structures (localised) to staff all the time, reducing productivity. They usually lack a deeper understanding of the operational requirements in the company and hence micro manage every task in just a short few months of their attachment. Managers lack power in this aspect, making their roles seemingly redundant and small issues that can be resolved were escalated unnecessarily. Global head office visits have changed; they (not all!) no longer stay humble and interact with floor staff and instead, select few were always seen giving side eyes as if we mean nothing in the company or do self-visits with their personal friends that seemingly conduct interrogative questioning.

The same goes for the retail level. Work attitudes were less than expected that prompts further internalized team conflicts over petty matters. Consultants that are applying should be reviewed much more stringently and take into consideration their daily work practices as some of them can be derogatory even in the presence of customers.

Departments always seem to lack budget for hiring new staff that will clearly help improve productivity but of course, profits first. Then planet. (Sorry, what people?)

Communication can be really bad between higher ups and people in-store. I worked for the store for over 2 years and saw 3 different coworkers successfully transfer to other markets with under 1 year of experience. When I requested a transfer I gave a month notice and was told by my manager in my last few meeting that my KPIs were looking good. Seeing that the success rate for transfers that I had seen so far was 100% I had high hopes. I also saw several different postings for the job I wanted to transfer with on several different platforms. In the end I didn’t hear from anyone. After waiting a week after I had moved I reached out to my manager and was told to reapply as an external. That makes no sense if management did their job and submitted my request to transfer. I would have preferred a clear rejection rather than just being ghosted. The most frustrating thing was that I passed up an opportunity at another job a few months before my transfer because I felt loyal to the company. This job would have paid more too. If only I had known my 2 years of commitment to the company would be worth nothing when it came down it I wouldn’t have been put in such a difficult situation. 
In terms of pay it feels random. I started at $16 several other workers began at $17 or $18 and sometimes it didnt seem dependent on experience or merit. One employee hired at $18 was so bad at the job they were fired at their 90 day review. I know in a company you’re not supposed to discuss pay, but people talk and they should realize that. 
Scheduling is a MESS. It seems that none of the store managers are trained in scheduling because I just don’t see how it can be so hard to coordinate 5 people’s schedules when they have fixed days available. If you have an open schedule I’d advise against telling them that. Give yourself at least a solid 2 days that you’re unavailable or you’ll find yourself working 6-10 days (sometimes more) in a row. Being paid overtime is great but your mental health is also really important. It’s also just the cherry on top of the cake when your store manager complains to you about being absolutely exhausted after working 6 days and needing a longer weekend. Store managers get away with a gross amount of bullying of consultants and not doing their jobs. If you choose to report your concerns or mention the harassment to your regional manager you will simply be brushed off due to the cliques and friendship groups between the management teams. I have worked in several locations and have seen long-standing, hard working consultants be pushed to the point of bursting into tears on the shop floor because of the behaviour of managers. The brand tries to push the concept of being "intellectually stimulating" and "mindful" in all aspects of functioning but it's all just  surface acting. Due to the prolific understaffing you will very often be left on your own or with only one other person to help during extremely busy periods (resulting in agressive customers) whilst the managers will sit in the backroom texting on their phone or just straight up go out for an hour long coffee with their friends during a shift (whilst obviously not on their break). There is no praise or acknowledgment for the hard work, blood sweat and tears that assistant managers and consultants put into running the stores; you are treated as disposable.

Two co-CEOs with too much ego to realize neither is qualified to run a company leads to the worst leadership team ever.  The situation is so bad, in fact, that their investor (KPCB) forced on them another executive - so now they have two CEOs and a President.  The culture is so bad that other than the original students (at Stanford) under Daphne and Andrew (in the CS department), most early employees leave as soon as they hit their one year vesting cliff.  Since so many employees leave in disgust, the leadership has begun request they sign a Non-Disparagement Agreement.  

Although the company built its reputation on a veneer of social impact and the motto of "Do what's best for the student," they've done nothing to back it up and lacks any clear mission statement.  Leadership has been brought in from YouTube and NetFlix, and even at 50+ people, there are only three educators on staff.  Although classes remain free, no effort has been spent to improve - or even measure - student learning or outcomes, and Coursera ignores even the most basic fact of education - that students do not learn by watching videos and regurgitating facts.  Then again, with a completion rate below 5% for most classes, it's not clear people even succeed in watching the videos.

I was recruited through a temping agency in SF, and the original description was easily fulfilled. I went into the job as if it were a temp job (I was mentally prepared for that) but the HR and management led me to believe that it would be a month or longer job. (I thought to myself, oh, this is great, there are great people here and it's a pretty cool job! Why not stay there?) 

Alas, two weeks into it (after putting in MANY hours over 40 per week, I might add) I got a call from my temp agent, telling me that IGG had found an "internal" solution to filling the role. That's fine, but... it was a Friday, and I had just left the office and was on my way home. And the HR manager/upper level management/whomever could have let me know beforehand so that I could at least bring my personal belongings back home with me. (Because of policies at the temping agency, once a role has been "finished" by the books the temp worker is not allowed back at the place of work.) I was shocked and upset at this news because I had felt like I was being inducted into the company and felt relatively secure in the position (for the ascribed amount of time, at least!) 

My complaint is that the HR management structure is terribly unprofessional and communication is barely present. It was offensive to hear the news from my temp agent and not from my boss at IGG. It was an awful experience, based solely on the unprofessional handling of my exit from the company.

If there's one thing that both current and former employees can agree on, it's the people. Throughout my multi-year tenure at TOMS I've met at least a hundred people who I would classify as either exceedingly brilliant, genuine, kind, approachable, or any combination of these traits. I've been fortunate to be surrounded by such talent and even call a few of my peers as friends. These are the ones who, like me, were drawn to TOMS because of how disruptive and progressive its business model was in retail; that in of itself makes it incredibly easy to connect with so many people at TOMS across various levels of the org structure and disciplines. Most everyone came to TOMS because they wanted to work for a company that stood for something other than just hitting sales targets, or being featured in fancy publications; inherently, you're going to meet a bunch of folks at TOMS that share a common interest in making a positive impact on the world. And I can't think of a better way to bring working professionals together...

Which leads to the next major plus of TOMS - the mission. Yes, it's real. And if you've never worked here but have read the articles online criticizing TOMS - the authors can go pound sand. Are there better ways to help communities than giving free shoes to those in need? Sure. Should we do something other than subsidize optical surgeries to improve the eyesight for the less fortunate that have limited or no vision? Maybe. But I can tell you the aid that TOMS provides is a hell of a lot better than being an armchair critic trying to tell a company how to run the philanthropic side of its operations. The famous Giving Trips are there to provide employees the experience of what our amazing partners tirelessly do day in, day out. These partners are the real heroes - they're the ones working out in the field in less than ideal conditions to improve the lives of others unselfishly. Do they need TOMS? Definitely not. But whenever our Giving team receives a thank you letter from the founders, presidents, etc. of these organizations expressing their gratitude of TOMS' commitment and partnership you can't help but feel proud that you work for the company that pioneered integrating philanthropy alongside a sustainable business. When you're on a Giving Trip and slip shoes on the feet of a kid that stares at their new pair of shoes in awe, looks up at you and smiles, then hugs you in the purest form of appreciation - nothing else matters, not even an online article trivializing the good that we do at TOMS.

I guess the last positive are the random, less-important perks - coffee bar, dogs in the office, laid-back environment, neat office space.
Working with a purpose and working with great people who are passionate about their job

Basically it is depressing to see the higher authorities and department mainly using "mouth power" for instructions to have their jobs done. And all this were weighted on the shoulder at all staffs in the retail space.  Most of the time, the instructions wasn't clear and expected that we have to knew it all and carried out the instructions perfectly. They hardly came to the stores to assist in preparation , and all things were done by the retail staffs and the office department team only come down to point fingers what were not done correctly.

Often when there were some situations we faced at retail floor, which needed advice from the higher authorities for solutions, it was mostly threw back to us for look for a solution ourselves. The teamwork in the office is so bad that I realized most are simply lazy and like to push tasks to others which ended to the retail staffs at the end.  And  helps and solutions are needed from certain department urgently, we always  saw a very slow response which took days or even week or no response at all. This is really bad.

The commission scheme is the most worrying part as we all knew the truth the consultants worked really hard to meet the store budget in order to get their incentive. In our case, the target given to stores were hardly fair.  Busier store were given high sky rocking budget, which can be 20-30% more as compared to light year. Incentive is only given if we meet 100% at store target, and nothing were given if we were only a few  thousands behind. But looking at the overall achievement , in actual fact we did a 15-18% growth as prepare to light year. The consultants always felt robbed and it bring down the morale of individuals.  Please understand the retail staffs are the one who bring in the business and with so most work loads to shoulder and end of the day not rewarded, most will probably decide to leave the environment to seek for a greener paths. It definitely not easy for consultants in retail spaces as they have so much to deal and absorb which a very strict require working environment.

There are so much more to say but i personally think these are the situations we are facing, especially situated one of the most challenging region in south east asia, where prices on products are even much more higher than most regions.

The new CEO Jim Alling appears as if he wants to fix the issues that plague TOMS but he is seemingly taking direction from some of the people that are large contributors to the issues. I whole-heartedly believe that Jim will fix some of what is wrong eventually.

The good people I met at Coursera joined to make a difference in the world. They, like me, wanted to provide affordable, high quality education at scale. Degrees from universities were not designed to be affordable or even a useful credential in the market. Chose the wrong degree, the wrong university or some combination of the two and you're stuck with a worthless degree and a ton of student loans.

Coursera started off disrupting the university degree system, but, under the reign of the CEO Rick and now Jeff, Coursera embraces the very system it was designed to disrupt. Why? Because of the MONEY. Coursera can offer 5x or more university expensive degrees than a university could. For example, under the original co-founders Daphne and Andrew, Coursera launched was University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign (UIUC)'s Masters of Data Science, a top 5 ranked Computer Science degree program, priced at very affordably $20,000. Coursera is now pressuring UIUC to increase the price of their degree program, so that Coursera could increase its profit margins.

If you love the mission of education, Coursera is not a good fit for you, because it tricks learners out of their hard earned money and flood the market with lower quality degrees (Remember 
University of Phoenix?). If you don't care about the mission and just want to make money, Coursera is not a good fit for you either. Don't think for a second any of that money Coursera is pocketing will end up your bank account. Coursera has a terrible leveling system designed to keep you in the lowest possible level and lowest pay. Working harder will NOT get you promoted, but your manager is happy to lie to you that it will.

Every company has problems, but having worked in over a dozen big and small companies, Coursera is by far in the worse shape. The problems are so systemic, there will need to be a massive overhaul in leadership and management at all levels. I am planning my exit and so are most individual contributors. Heed my warning. Coursera survives by suckering good people into working for the company. You will either be brainwashed into a soulless minion or leave disgusted with the company you once loved.

Since edX was acquired by 2U, there has been changes and now all of them are good: we lost our offices which also affected on our work and connections. I haven't met most of my colleagues in person and probably I'll never meet them. Before 2020, edX allowed some employees to travel to other offices at the company's expense, but that stopped since we're all remote and lost our offices. The excuse is that 'there is no business need', said by those that still travel and meet people in person. I understand edX goals and mission after all these years, but I honestly don't know much about 2U... and it's been two years since the acquisition. I feel they don't really care about edX and probably the other way around too. I tried to meet some 2U employees, I was successful at meeting a few... but it was impossible to meet others, and I tried, but the interest needs to work on both ways. There are few opportunities to grow, we just get to work on side projects and tasks. I think most of us stay here because of other benefits: decent salary, flexibility, good environment overall and so on. I honestly see myself staying here for more years as long as we keep those benefits, even if I never get to meet any of my colleagues in person and I remain stuck in the same position with just some new tasks and projects every now and then. With the acquisition and changes, I fear edX will become more strict and maybe we'll lose some of our benefits or flexibility... I'll definitely consider leaving then, with sadness, and probably will look for a job in a company that has an office but allows to wfh half of the time.

Management and clients have lots of grand ideas about what should happen in the education industry in general, and many of those ideas had rough implementations thrown together in order to get into the next headline and claim market dominance. Unfortunately, those rough implementations often had very little follow through once the headline was achieved, which left the organization with a lot of expectations in a very short amount of time and little ability to meet those expectations. Even worse, there are legacy implementations of many good ideas that the organization has to maintain in order to support early adopters, meaning that it has a more complicated political maneuvering space for any innovations that it wants to attempt in the future.

Like so many others here, all I want is to find a decent job so I can leave this side show circus.

Finding a job that feels truly meaningful is difficult. Indiegogo is a place where you get this. I feel like I'm helping people achieve something. And while business strategies shift over time (and some people are bound to like them, and some aren't), I don't think Indiegogo and its employees have ever lost a genuine desire to make change. This translates to the company culture, too. It's really inclusive, definitely the most inclusive place I have ever worked, and leadership seems committed to thoughtfully understanding how employees are feeling and making changes to make things better. I feel supported, challenged, and happy. I think the company strategy and mission are headed in a positive direction, and I'm excited to be part of what we're doing.

Culture of fear permeates every corner of the business - people are sacked for no reason and with no notice.

Base pay and employment terms and conditions are pitiful and not competitive. This is covered up with staff benefits that get good PR (puppy leave, free beer, discount in bars etc.)

There is no structure to pay progression and most of the time you are told there is a pay and recruitment freeze however you watch as they burn money on vanity projects (e.g. tv network, airline, damaging marketing campaigns).

There is no professional development. Performance reviews, objectives, targets, employee check ups are hit or miss depending on what department you are in. This is not a place to build a career.  

Don't dare speak up, raise legitimate issues, act professionally or try to use data and facts to solve problems - this is a one way ticket to your P45.

Turnover of staff is wild but in particular at a senior level.  I had 6 line managers in 2 years. This means you are permanently having to prove yourself to a new manager, never getting consistent leadership and changing your work priorities to suit the next new manager's agenda.

Based on how leadership acts, it seems like vans is speeding towards financial disaster. Almost every other day for several months there have been 911 calls to add brand-degrading promotions or to completely change the marketing approach overnight, despite no real movement on business trend. Senior leadership members seem misaligned and routinely undermine one another. VPs micromanage teams even at the lowest level to push forward these exhausting power struggles. To make matters worse, promotions merit raises transfers wellness days etc seem to have been repeatedly frozen, leaving employees burned out. The constant emergency environment and unrealistic requests cause rifts between teams who used to collaborate well, leaving everyone on edge. I’m sorry to say that Vans/VF is not an engaging place to work anymore.

What a disappointment. For a company that touts the importance of mental health, wellness, and giving back to the community, it’s unfortunate that they don’t lead their teams with the same focus and compassion. 
Depending on the team you are on, you were likely hired as a remote employee, but TOMS is now requiring remote employees to come onsite weekly, monthly, or quarterly at the employee’s expense. This rule and mandate applies to all levels of employees. In other words, entry level or middle management employees are paying $300+ a night on hotels and hundreds of dollars on gas / plane tickets, etc to comply. Executive leadership might be able to afford this, but most employees can’t. 
This burden adds undue stress financially and mentally. Meaning, employees are fearful of losing their jobs if the don’t take on the financial burden. This is also reinforced by a bully / intimidation leadership approach that exists within some teams. Employees are afraid to speak up to leaders, as they will be in their line of fire in a private or public forum.

Personality cult style culture; if you want to progress you have to 'Be BrewDog' 24/7. Promotions seem to happen as a personality contest as opposed to based on competency.

Refuse to change their security provider despite multiple complaints of sexual assault from staff and cases of customers being assaulted, endangering staff

- Pure corporate greed. Their profit margins were suffering, so they laid off over 100 of the district and regional managers last year and just did another massive layoff internally for the managers/supervisors in stores. They have cut the headcount, labor hours, and pay rates down to the bare minimum, leaving skeleton crews, but ramping up the job requirements and expectations. “Squeezing blood from a turnip”, so to speak. 
- They also hired FAR less qualified people in management after the layoff because they’re “cheaper labor”, and trust me.. You feel it. The environment has become toxic and no one is competent in their jobs in the higher up positions, so the work falls on the shoulders of those beneath them. 
- Again, as an attempt for the company to save as much money as possible, they have cut nearly every incentive the employees used to be able to earn based on performance. Yet, they now have a constant rotation of promos available for the customers. They want more and more from their workers while they continue to strip what little they offered in return.
- Vans used to be about “The Van Doren Way”. Putting their people first. Employees and customers included. Now that they’ve been absorbed by VF Corporation, it’s just another parasitic company feeding off their hosts.

Unfortunately, ever since L’Oreal acquired Kiehl’s in the year 2000, the quality of products and core values of this company have steadily gone downhill. In 2017, the company cleaned house and got rid of their longtime, loyal employees. Kiehl’s brought in a new president (Megan Grant) who was given the directive to “stop the bleeding.” She is ruthless! 

Although Megan Grant gives lip service to “sympathy” and empathy training, the work environment under her leadership is toxic and hostile. Employee morale is the pits. There is a revolving door of turnover in the home office and fleet-wide attrition rates are through the roof in all of their brick-and-mortar stores. 

The cutthroat sales environment and lack of a fair bonus structure in freestanding Kiehl's stores creates malcontent and mental health risks.

Notably, the current president of Kiehl’s was transferred from Body Shop, where she sucked the heart and soul out of their corporate culture, too. In a well-publicized fiasco, L’Oreal was forced to sell Body Shop due to low sales and a controversy surrounding animal testing.

Not only is Kiehl’s heartless when it comes to how they treat their employees, they are NOT cruelty-free when it comes to testing on animals. In order to sell Kiehl's products in China, Kiehl’s Since 1851 continues to test many of their products on animals.

People - I know I just sang praises about all the amazing colleagues, and while that's true, there's also a fair share of either incompetent, apathetic, "I'm here to collect a paycheck," or any combination of these horrible characteristics that dilutes those that are trying to improve TOMS. Sure, I get there will always be entry to mid-level peeps that just don't care or know about contributing to the company to realize its full potential. But when you have this kind of riff-raff in the upper ranks like VPs and execs...set sail for fail. That's not to say there aren't any good leaders in management - of course there are. But all it takes are a few bad apples in key positions, making hasty or bad decisions because they don't know what's actually going on at the ground level and with a company of our relatively small size it's pretty easy to get up to speed on the details. The fact that these apathetic/incompetent leaders don't know who to tap into at TOMS to get the accurate data or info - that's a reflection of how out of touch they are with their teams or the goals of the company. Some of these "coasters" have since been ousted, but rest assured a good amount remain in the upper ranks.

Onto a related topic...the current state of the company. I don't know what I'm allowed to disclose, so I'll play it safe and keep it general - we've made several bad decisions in the past few years since the brand exploded; decisions that have wasted unfathomable amounts of resources - time, money, and effort. Decisions that have cost the company and are still haunting us to this day. Decisions that have forced the entire organization to lose focus and always be in constant state of chaos. Decisions that have led to missed opportunities to continue growing the brand. Just...bad decisions. And the worst thing? Besides the fact that it's self-inflicted, it is never ending - there's a difference between fast-paced (recruiter buzzword) and chaotic (reality at TOMS). What I mean by that: most of the major projects we work on - there's little to no planning...want to know what happens when you don't carefully plan out a big, cross-functional project? I'll tell you - missed deadlines and budget constraints, frustration, gaps ("Oh I thought YOU were going to do it"), and in general a lot of finger pointing which ultimately leads to low morale. It's gotten to the point that pretty much all the executors in projects expect them to go sideways or lose steam before we even have the project kick-off, which is sad. Then it's just a vicious cycle because we need to work on the next project and because someone neglected to be accountable and plan out the milestones with realistic targets - again, it flies off the rails. Rinse and repeat. So what this long-winded paragraph boils down to is no accountability at TOMS. I'm all for giving people second chances but if someone is running a project or brokering a deal that if it goes badly, could represent a huge miss in sales or cost us a ton of money - someone needs to be held responsible and take a demotion, be put on a PIP, or something. But no - that's not very "TOMSy" so we let these key decision-makers continue to make the same mistakes over and over.

You know what else isn't TOMSy? Staying in your lane and not overlapping, duplicating someone else's efforts, or creating redundancy. The problem is because the TOMS way is to let people come into their own with little to no guidance from a seasoned mentor, there ends up being 5 people trying to achieve the same result and doing it in 5 different ways without even knowing there were other people working on the exact same thing. And then letting people do important tasks that need to be reviewed/monitored because they have little experience in this area - I've lost count how many times I've seen poor execution because nobody was communicating or providing mentorship or asking for help. So what other companies call "exposure to a variety of disciplines" TOMS just really need to stop offering this and clearly define roles, or figure out how to better allow people to try out new things under supervision to ensure some semblance of quality is delivered. Also, this used to not be as much of a problem as it is now but there are too many cooks in the kitchen i.e. we're still too top heavy as an organizational hierarchy; decisions that should be quickly made so we can adapt take too long, and it creates this weird dynamic where it has to propogate through multiple unnecessary decision-makers and/or people who are basically pass-through (they provide no input or don't make decisions) so it's literally like you are setting up a meeting to tell someone something just so they can relay exactly what you said to someone else. But the person you told will probably misinterpret and there's all these translation issues where you are playing that game with cups connected with a string and when you hear back what the last person thought the first person said - it ends up being completely different!

Then all the other cool, fun things we used to do as a company to maintain our culture and the friendly vibes - happy hours, annual trips...those are all gone. Bonuses are pretty terrible since they're tied to company performance, and merit increases are meager. Yes, these cost money and we're clearly not in the same position we were in 5 years ago but in the interest of disclosure to candidates - aside from the business model, there are no real perks and we're beginning to just feel like another company getting corporatized by private equity swooping in to set us up for a sale event.

I feel so fortunate to have been a Coursera employee for over 3 years. The things that drew me to Coursera remain consistent: We get to work on one of the most important missions in the world, to transform lives through educational access, with some of the smartest and most caring people I've ever worked with. Since our new CEO Jeff joined, what has changed for the positive has been clarity of our business strategy with a strategy that is driving tremendous business growth with huge future potential and a strong and unified leadership team who is working together to set direction and vision for the company. 

Ultimately I come to work everyday because I believe we are building a path so that anyone, anywhere, no matter where they start can build a path to wherever they want to go and whoever they want to be which is incredibly powerful. We see learners first hand all the time for whom this is reality and this inspires me and excites me about all that is in our future. 

We also get to do it with a team who is incredibly committed, collaborative, and talented which creates a much better culture and environment than I've ever been part of in my professional career. 

Finally, our business is doing extremely well which means we are continuing to grow our impact and continuing to invest into the business which creates opportunities for internal mobility and career development. I've seen countless examples of people who have learned and grown into new roles within the company and advance their careers.

I've been at Coursera over a year and can honestly say, hands down, this is the best place I have ever worked. The opportunities are growth are endless, as long as you're willing to push for them. You really need to proactive and hustle to succeed here, but it's worth it. Looking back, I'm proud of how much I've grown since I've been at Coursera. I don't think that would be the case at a larger company.

Other pros:
- Smart, dedicated colleagues who genuinely care about people and education
- Ownership. This is huge. I've always felt my managers went above and beyond to make sure I felt ownership of my work and recognized my impact. 
- Flexible work hours & work from home Wednesdays 
- Unlimited vacation people actually take regularly (huge thumbs up to this)
- Lunch, dinner, snacks. Healthcare. The usual valley perks. 
- ***There is a huge ability to make an impact, not only at a personal growth level, not only at a company level, and most importantly, at a global level. I can't think of any other company that has the opportunity to do good for others like Coursera.***

BrewDog is making it their mission to become the best employer ever. No business is perfect and as we are still pretty young and growing at an insane speed, it's easy to run into unexpected problems. However, the people team are ace and constantly listening to feedback from teams. They have implemented many new benefits in the last 12 months, including free private healthcare, an unbelievable enhanced pension contribution, and equal end of year bonus for ALL employees. 

They have also recently launched a world-class staff and management training scheme that goes hand in hand with a learning and development fund for each employee. There are also great progression opportunities across the board; packaging teams are put through their apprenticeships, and there is a great bar management development programme too. Lots of people have moved up through the ranks from junior positions and have been given chances unheard of in other companies.

My mission here is not to write a full review, just to correct some statements in earlier reviews that are incorrect or out of date.

Indiegogo has good market share already but still needs to establish itself as a sustainable business. We made good progress in 2015 on identifying and serving our entrepreneur market (e.g. InDemand) and you'll see more of that in 2016. Our social mission is still alive and well, it's just not so mixed in with the rest of the business.

'Work-life balance' is about as good as one could expect from a company at this stage. Four weeks of vacation is standard. New parents get two months of leave, and leaders set an example by taking it. There are also standard holidays plus your birthday, and early closures on the days before holidays.

Regarding diversity, six of the 15 members of the coordination team (the company's highest-level decision-making group) are women, to say nothing of one of the three founders (all of whom are still with the company). Overall Indiegogo is relatively diverse for an Internet company. Engineering has fallen behind lately, although there is energy behind getting back on track there.

Finally, some employees may have been asked to write Glassdoor reviews shortly after joining, but I wasn't, and if it's a broad policy I'm not aware of it.

TOMS is still very much a startup while being a mid size company. Both of those have very different implications. In one way we are still nimble and able to move quickly where needed. But, thanks to Bain and new leadership we have a lot of processes being added that are creating a much more efficient and effective business.

If you enjoy a challenge and want to learn to grow as a professional, this is a great place with opportunities to do that if you are willing to put in the effort on your own. If you want an easy job where you can sit back, collect a paycheck, and have an inflated title this is not the place for you.

TOMS is 100% giving One for One with all of our products which is our commitment to all. And, there are so many ways we are improving lives beyond that, through our employment opportunities, friendly work environment and perks, last mile budget (which makes sure we are not a financial burden to our giving partners), local manufacturing, and so many other ways that you can only fully experience by working here.

Our leadership team is 95% full and stronger than any leadership team we have had in the past. And, our employees are committed to our mission and want to make the world a better place. 

I have had ups and downs here, but it has and continues to be a wonderful ride that I am incredibly grateful for. I have never been more excited than I am right now for where TOMS is headed.

1. This company is historically anti-union. This is remarkable considering that Sierra Nevada posted the 3rd highest sales volume during 2020 . Many comparable breweries have multiple unions operating internally to advocate for employee interests.
2. Employees are grossly underpaid. Despite Sierra Nevada's tremendous success over the past 2 decades, employees continue struggling to pay their bills. This is true for both warehouse and professional-level staff. I know of at least 10 employees with bachelor's degrees whom must work multiple jobs to keep the lights on at their homes. In conducting a compensation analysis, it is clear that Sierra Nevada is in a lag position for most company occupations relative to virtually every comparable competitor.

I think most of the cons of working at Indiegogo are the result of growing pains. The industry and company is expanding at a rapid rate and we sometimes can't keep up. 

For example, while I really think this is an opportunity, one challenge we face is that a lot of our internal tools haven't been optimized yet. This means that there is a lot of room for improvement which I find exciting, but it is frustrating at times when things break or have to be done manually.

We have had a bad habit of overcommitting and lacking focus. A lot of projects have been started with positive outlooks and overly-ambitious deadlines only to come to a grinding halt when things need to be re-prioritized. Some of these projects never see the light of day again or become obsolete by the time we get around to them. 

Advancement in the organization is unclear for now. I want to hold off on judgement until I have been here longer and have a clearer sense of my own career path, but for now I feel that there isn't a good system in place for people to advance within the company. 

Even though we are experiencing some frustration as we expand, we always look at how we can overcome them and adapt. We are always iterating to better our tools and product; we just implemented a new process of OKRs to focus our team efforts; and our HR department has a track record for listening to employees and providing new improvements when suggested like a 401k. 

I firmly believe all of these cons will be addressed (at least in part) in the next year as we adjust to becoming a larger company.

They dictate how you dress and speak. They actually have written guides on the language you are expected to use in conversation and in email, and what you should wear. The language code is honestly extremely alienating and inappropriate as you are expected to speak like a middle-upper class, middle aged white woman, and this of course is extremely difficult for non-natives to adapt to.  Even the dress code is unfair - you are expected to wear certain materials and they offer some discounts with local brands, however even with the discounts the clothing is too expensive. To be blunt, all these things are modeled from one of the founders - an aging lady who clearly lives an extremely priveleged life and, as interesting as she is, is sightly snobby and judgemental in a way that she disapproves of peoples speech patterns, ineterests and clothing. They take her personality adn inject this into the business, and you'll see this if you visit a store and pay attention to the way the staff interact wit you. The entire thing is scripted - and very clever and natural feeling script - but a script nonetheless. For a company that claims to value culture and diversity, I find it shocking at just how up itself it is in the whitest, most privileged sense. Not to mention the fact that everyone will wear clothing from other cultures, but will be the first extreme socialist liberals to scream 'cultural appropriation'. 

On the same topic of etiquette and codes - theese actually breed an extremely passive aggressive behaviour on occasion. Where you are expected to use certain polite statements in all your email - the receptionists  and other staff will send extremely passive aggressive emails using eloquent and flowery language. It's grating and the expectation to pad your emails honestly becomes hampering over time, especially when you simply need to get things done. 

They are also painfully indecisive, especially regarding interviews. my manager had 9 interviews before they hired them, and they wanted to do 10 but he declined. Most people go through at least 3-4 interviews and you'll meet 2-3 people in each interview. They also like to promote internally and unfortnately, the balance is in the wrong dorection because they do not train people - only promote them, so you end up with senior people not having a clue how to do things, and have grown within the Aesop bubble so they lack outside ideas and perspectives.

They make a huge profit but don't invest it enough in benefits and training.

The CEO is not based in melbourne. He moved to the UK. Yet Melbourne are the head offices. This means senior staff in core functions have a lack of direction. it also means the CFO is acting as de facto CEO and he isn't a nice person, nor is he well liked. - No work/life balance - except some emails/meetings/calls/slacks in the evening and even during the weekends. Employees are giving everything, but even as a top performer, you get very little recognition.
- Some sales techniques are completely outdated and the micromanagement via metrics is insane. EVERYTHING you do is recorded the second you’re logged in. You’re expected to to volume regardless of the results. 
- Pay is good, but keep in mind that you easily do the job of 3 people at time.
- No room for career progression. Promotions are rare. I would say you need to be in the top 10% continuously for a year to get a chance to get a raise. Moving department is nearly impossible.
- Territories are never discussed with you: it is either you take it or leave the company. Some territories are great, others are very difficult to work with or green, so having roughly the same quota in the team makes it very unfair for some reps. You’re basically lucky or you’re not. You’re being assigned to good and collaborative AEs or you’re not.
- Huge turnover - lots of people get sick or burned out. I stayed a year and almost everyone left in the EMEA sales team (I am talking about at least 20 departures between SDRs and AEs). Besides a few, the ones left are looking elsewhere or stay because they have no choice. Staff retention is not a thing at Coursera.

They used to be slightly more lax in approving extra hours, but they have been trying to cut down on their spending and don't approve those extra hours unless they need an emergency fill for a coverage spot.
Upward momentum seems slow right now since we are going through changes on the backend of the company. Positions are being aggregated so that senior roles take on more than one function and position titles are being changed. To preface: I don't think these are actually cons, especially when these comments are measured against competitors. It's more to maybe set expectations right about the direction of the brand (and may not even be accurate at the time you're reading this).

Many reviews here feel outmoded- Aesop has been in the midst of a change of tectonic proportions. Smaller (yet significant) traditions of creating a human-to-human retail experience that constitutes a convincing refutation of the pressure-selling and shiny promises of the beauty industry are no longer even mentioned to new hires, disappearing completely with turnover. Campaign messages and targets can feel forced and ironically build up resentment in some consultants when longtime Aesopians only buy from the Hand Care range or "refuse" to purchase the Parsley Seed or Perfect Hydrating Cream because they are longtime devotees to Primrose (no points to guessing which are more expensive/fulfill specific KPIs). 

And yet, this Omnichannel-driven shift in company culture is completely natural in the grand scheme of things. Aesop at times feels like it's "solo-carrying" the Natura stock based on breakdowns; its growth is undeniable. The global targets for the years to come are ambitious and dependent on entering new markets and converting more to Fragrance and Skin Care. Accomplishing this would mean more in-house research and anticipation for new, exciting sustainable products, but is currently resulting in a halo effect on said products taught into new consultants' hosting habits. Some clients find this unnerving, but new clients would genuinely probably not be able to parse it out of the overall, still pleasant store visit experience. One final gripe on that note however would be pricing, which at times can feel entirely confusing. See above for an elaboration on the price range (my rating: fair), but it's within the ranges that the questions come up. Take the newest fragrance range, Othertopias, three new perfumes a full Benjamin/Borden more than Hwyl for.... reasons (in all seriousness, it's the new techniques and ingredients the Nose used among other reasons, but the explanation stops when clients and consultants ask exactly one more question: why are they all priced the same?). As a consultant, there will be other products that may confuse you in their pricing, but I would advise to relate it back to how they make you personally feel! There are various ways to navigate this, but it's still something that will linger for me personally.

Anyhow, the tl;dr is that the slower, more personal approach to in-store selling through conversation is being supplanted with personalized, multichannel advertisement, meaning emails with products you like/are likely to purchase, social media banners that would make some past employees cringe and reminders about your purchasing history made by consultants during store visits. 

I think these cons are outweighed by the approach to product development, absolutely KILLER copywriting and the insight into art and design that Aesop conveys through specific newsletters, a colourful intranet for employees to share experiences and interests and the care they put into architecture and store elements.

BrewDog is the best place I've ever worked. I've worked in finance, oil and gas and retail companies before this, and none of them came close. There's obviously been a lot of talk about 'toxic culture' over the last year. I don't know all the people who've alleged this, but I know a lot of them, and if you blindly believe what is said, you're mistaken. Nobody who criticises the company seems to ask current employees what they think. I've been really happy at BrewDog. I work with nice people, I like the work I do, and the pay and benefits are great. The CEO is pretty nice, from what I can tell. The HR team are really helpful. I've never seen another company put so much effort into mental wellbeing. That doesn't make a great newspaper headline though.

- The CEO has a large platform and brand that is positioning the company well, more than I think people realize. If the company improves, this type of visibility will be positive for everyone who works here. While some people feel this is not good, I think it brings a lot of value. I think the CEO works hard to balance this. He is at every all-hands meeting, he has a true open-door policy, and he responds in all our Slack channels...he does more than I have seen other CEOs do. 
- Having a Black CEO has been amazing, as a person of color, I appreciate this deeply. 
- The leadership team has had a lot of change in the past few years and it feels like the company is getting on track, a lot of bad leaders are gone now. 
- We have an important product that can change the lives of many people, if you want to be a part of making the world a better place or purpose-driven work, Kickstarter will make sure you feel and understand you are a part of something bigger than you 
- Kickstarter will support growth but the company is small so sometimes you can only get promoted if someone leaves. It could be a good stepping stone though (if you are on the right team/with the right manager).

One of the most important reasons that I chose to develop myself in the startup environment is to get my hands on different things and acquire different skill sets. Career development and employee growth opportunities are constant struggles at indiegogo - there is no systematic way facilitating programs like inter-company externship, or giving employees, especially the junior folks, the opportunities to try new projects or even new departments.

Company-level goals and strategies are mostly determined behind the doors, and senior management sometimes is not communicative about major policy changes or updates. Some departments get lost in the chaotic prioritization process, and do not get access to enough resources compared to others.

Junior employees have limited opportunity interacting with the management team. There is no mentorship (another important reason I joined a startup for) encouraged as part of the company culture.

This is a company that will have high expectations and work you to the bone and then when you are exhausted, they are so understaffed that you can’t take a sick day. 
Sales consultants have long hours and are required to stand all day, no exceptions. As stores are always understaffed, they expect you to pick up the slack of others and do two jobs. I worked as a full time employee and acted essentially as a stand in manager being paid the same hourly wage as the new people I was required to train and onboard. They gave out raises to anyone, but for people who have been with the company for long and worked hard, they would cap them off at a certain point. They give everyone the same raises (whether you worked hard or not) to make you feel appreciated but at the end of the day the real hard workers aren’t shown anything worth their time. 
New stores are opened way too early, again leaving the consultants to figure everything out and pick up the pieces left behind by head office and contractors. Stores are designed and put together poorly, wasting material and time and it takes months if not literal years (not exaggerating) to get something repaired in a store. 
Although Aesop does stand behind what they tell customers (for now), as the company grows I have seen internal changes that mirror a larger company and actions that head towards problematic territory and further away from the “personal” approach to managing people and selling to people.

Aesop’s values for sustainability is my personal favorite pro of the company. The company feels so small when you are apart of it. They don't know how to be a company of their size. The core players of the business work with each-other in the same way they always have, the same way they did when Indiegogo was a < 20 person company, but they also have a ton of "big company" things (like OKRs and tons of departments and teams with different goals). They are way bigger than their "heart" operates, and are really big into "fearlessness" as a way of trusting people to do what they need to do, but fearlessness can't always solve the issues with gaps in management in some places, and too much management in others. (I mean... are people on the leaves supposed to be able to say we don't need the trunks?). They organize their strategy around KPIs, but typical of most startups, this results in large swaths of the product being essentially abandoned because no department has a KPI that would justify fixing it (Ahem... E-mail notifications). Multiple departments are responsible for overlapping layers of the experience, and those departments are often not marching to the same drum or KPIs. For example, both product and marketing take responsibility for emails but each has different goals and there isn't a cohesive way to incentivize either department to make the experience of unsubscribing from emails better. Both design, marketing and sales create graphic content for different parts of the experience. However, marketing is encouraged to posture Indiegogo based on 3rd party "voice and tone" people, meanwhile the design departments internal work on voice and tone is often discordant with marketing's directions. This rift is because the masters of these departments are marching to different drums (led by KPIs that would indirectly engender incompatible execution), but in execution the beats need to fit together and often don't. This means people's "fearless" autonomy is often overlapped by others' fearless autonomy. It's a bit too much ritual, ceremony and corporate rhetoric that doesn't really fit into how i think they want to operate. It's hard to be truly fearless at their size.

Indiegogo is made up of smart, driven, and clever people working together toward an admirable goal. The culture is transparent and ripe with opportunities to learn and grow. They have some of the best benefits I’ve had with great work/life balance. The leadership team is caring with an awesome open-door policy. They are often in the trenches working with each of the teams sharing knowledge and providing guidance.

For years Kickstarter has had a leadership in some form of crisis or another. When Yancey took over the leadership was mostly Yancey’s friends or people who’d worked closely with him for years. Then he hired some outside people to clean it up and that caused a war. Then things calmed down but there was clearly always a Cold War with Perry. I don’t know what happened but then Perry took over again. Yancey publicly promised a CEO search and that turned out to be a lie. Now the cycle restarts with Perry’s friends at the top. 
It’s not that there haven’t been good leaders hired in or elevated. But they have generally been driven out or quit in a matter of months. 
All the while the board does nothing. It’s not clear there is any accountability for the CEOs. 
And for years we didn’t have proper HR leadership with the experience to navigate this. 
It’s all very sad.

They expect a VERY specific type of employee;
- nice but not too 'friendly' otherwise it's not professional
- we are told to 'make a connection' and 'quiet nonconformity' but apparently talking to customers about how their day is, or what brings them to the area for work/travel etc is not professional and too 'friendsy' 
- staff that have been working there for a few years talk to the manager about what you're doing wrong, whether you're in the backroom more when they're not around etc and can't feel like you're friends with such senior staff as you always feel watched as if they're the manager
- EVERY little thing you do that is not the perfect aesopian is scrutinised to the point where it is very unattainable unless you're a typical 'hipster/brunswick/fitzroy/vegan' style employee who thinks aesop if life - you can't make conversation with customers about things unrelated to product apparently as it's too bubbly and unprofessional 
- manager feedback is sometimes inaccurate and completely wrong (they are not usually on the floor)
- head office people often think they are on a high horse and when they visit the store they are observing and judging your every move and will talk to the managers about it
- the company as a whole can be pretentious and a bit 'wanky' - with some products essentially being 'anti-aging' (anti-oxidant/vitamin C) but we are not allowed to say anti-aging

A very real response I was given when I brought up concerns of people not wanting to be touched, or sales associates not comfortable doing that (especially in a pandemic): "People don't know they want it until it's happening, and then they enjoy it." Creepy. 
- Overall cult-like culture from upper management, CEO, VM and middle management

TOMS is a company with a passion for giving making the people friendly and supportive of one another; they also like to have fun together. Different company traditions like the opportunity to go on a Giving trip, attend a company-hosted, 3-day annual retreat, participate in local service projects, and have various events and happy hours make it fun. 

Most folks work on a laptop and their desks are in large spacious areas. This promotes face to face interaction and group brainstorming for "the next big thing". 

The office environment is fun - spiral slides take you from the second floor down the the first floor where a barista serves up your favorite coffee or tea beverage free of charge every morning. You can expect to be challenged to an afternoon ping pong game to get over the daily slump, and the dog friendly environment means cuddly friends to say hello to during your walk through the hallways. 

A different food truck comes everyday during breakfast and lunch in case you didn't pack one for yourself. You can burn off the additional calories in the free, nightly fitness programs offered on-site. Classes range from kickboxing to yoga and TRX. 

It's not uncommon to leave work with your colleagues to get happy hour or grab dinner together. Your desk will likely get decorated on your birthday, and the several lounge areas allow you to do some work on your laptop from a couch with your feet up.
Generous discounts Some good people; training team people are lovely.
Tough work environment, hard to socialize and work with other co-workers

This review has been a long time coming. And regardless of the cultural issues that plague Indiegogo's management styles and decision-making processes, I'd like this review to serve as a transparent breakdown of why you should avoid the recruiting mumbo jumbo and ask for the figures.

Before we dive into the cons, Here are the pros:

- Mostly great people to work with, especially those in the entry level to middle management positions. These people are talented, unencumbered by the daily politics of Indiegogo and really don't know any better. They're just awesome, smart and eager to get work done.

- Nicer office space than some places

From the moment I interviewed at TOMS I knew what an incredible company and family this organization was. Following a rapid interview process and coming onboard, I was taken through an extensive and excellent onboarding/training program. It is evident that the leadership team is strategic and intentional about their decisions,  which trickles down to every level of the organization. They are led by a phenomenal CEO, who is extremely personable and passionate about the brand. My interactions thus far with colleagues have been remarkeably positive - with most hungry to mentor and learn from one another. This organization truly values their employees both on a professional and personal level.

NO accountability - many senior and junior level employees have been able to get away with unacceptable behavior (stealing, lying, disrespect to their jr. level employees) because C level turns a blind eye or feels unequipped to handle disciplinary actions. 
Freelance/contract staff are not valued or rewarded for their hard work, although they keep the company functioning and in operation.
Many people have been discouraged by lack of & change in leadership. The two biggest thorns in the side of the company are last-minute changes to enormous campaigns and projects, and un-vetted & unequipped director- and VP-level leaders. 
TOMS has lost an uncountable number of talented people because of the stifling environment created by the above, along with unrealistic budgets, and an uneven distribution of power and resources.  Many manager and coordinator level workers are not properly managed or monitored for efficiency, and abuse company resources and time due to the lack of attention placed from the mid-level down.

The company is changing and they’re asking you to do a lot more then what they want to pay you. You’re obligated to stand up and do more then what they’re paying you for because they say “growth is an option” but people stay in their same positions for years upon years. They don’t want to give you raises based on your performance because it’s “by chance” since you don’t make commission. The bonus structure is based off your goal for the month, so even if you work your butt off and others aren’t they still get the bonus; or you don’t get bonus at all. They also changed it to where you have bonus be based on your “Trend” from the last two months so they raise your goals to make it more unachievable if you are meeting your marks. I worked at TOMS for almost five years. I started as an intern back in 2010, when the company had only given one million pairs of shoes, and I moved to full time employment in a few departments over the course of my time there. I worked long hours, the pay was below what other folks in my job areas were working, and I would not have traded a moment of that five years to work for anyone else. The magic inside that company was palpable. The energy employees gave to one another was positive and wonderful. I grew as a person and as a professional, and I could not have asked for a better start to my career. Like any experience, what you have to gain is equal to what you put in. I went in with an open mind, I was ready to work hard. As a result, I was able to learn from some of the brightest minds in marketing and international development; I was able to gain exposure to multiple fields in a startup environment; I have an incredibly rich and diverse network. Almost every time I think about my days there, I smile. 

I also would not have been able to work at the next incredible company I found without having worked at TOMS first. It was an irreplaceable learning experience.

Dog-friendly office, benefits were great for my needs, coffee-bar, and outside partnerships that created fun free events like Sofar Sounds, Into Action events, happy hours, open mic nights, etc. Fun for a single younge lifestyle. Biggest pro was working for a brand that truly kept it's vision on it's mission. Which is why I was so bummed that my coworkers were so cold and clicque-y. I left solely due the environment in my department.

However, there are significant downsides that potential employees should be aware of. The pay is notably low, to the point where it's not uncommon for employees to qualify for food stamps and state health care, which is embarrassing for a company that positions itself as a luxury brand. The management style is problematic, with many employees' concerns and issues being ignored by higher-ups. Despite frequent promises of opportunities for growth and development within the company, Aesop often hires externally, leaving many employees feeling strung along.
The work culture also has a cult-like atmosphere, which can be uncomfortable and off-putting. It's disheartening to work for a luxury brand and yet earn so little that, even with an employee discount, the hourly wage equates to less than the cost of a bottle of soap. Overall, while there are some positive aspects to working at Aesop, the cons significantly overshadow them.

It's really nice to be part of a company that truly believes in a better tomorrow and does everything it can to make the world a better place - a world where equity, justice and good exists. This company truly cares deeply about its mission and its employees. It knows that working for positive change takes hard work and genuine effort from everyone. This company is all about action when it counts and really uses its money to help where it counts most. That's been even more evident during these times of great social unrest and a pandemic with so many in need. And while it takes care of the world, it also takes care of its employees. For example, when the pandemic first started and before it was even a thing for companies to do, TOMS gave ( and continues to give) employees a $600 stipend to set up their own home office and gives monthly stipend of $50 for internet and another $50 for cell phone. And with all the social unrest that's been going on, TOMS has gathered its employees multiple times to listen, learn and discuss how social inequity and injustice is hurting us all and learn how to become strong allies. And for business matters, employees can ask questions during our regular virtual All Staff meetings or Global Brand conferences where the LT will answer directly and honestly - we just have to ask the questions.
 The company feels focused and aligned and I see a bright future ahead. I'm excited to continue being part of a company that cares so deeply about doing good in the world and especially for each other. This is the kind of place where your coworkers become your friends for life. People really love and support each other in a very genuine way. Even in the virtual environment you can feel how warm and friendly TOMS continues to be.
