After 6 months working here, I can say the people are what make this place special: everyone I work with is kind, committed, passionate, driven––really leaning into the company values which are expressed top-down as well as bottom-up. It produces a healthy workplace environment that maximizes productivity and keeps it light and fun along the way.
Leadership is generally aligned and clear on their visions, and take the time to ensure visibility and clear communication with strategies, business metrics, and shifting priorities. This helps everyone understand exactly how they fit into the bigger picture, and even influence their current et of priorities based on the expressed priorities of the business. Results in a sense of collective buy-in and motivation/group morale.

Customer service component can be emotionally exhausting, the brand wants true ambassadors who are patient, encouraging, and have/can retain extensive product knowledge. Some interactions are quick, but many are extremely long where customers often overshare. You might end up spending 45 minutes with a customer to guide them through some products. Also expect to be comfortable demonstrating on their hands via washing, moisturizing, perfuming, etc. You are constantly on your feet—depends on manager perhaps—and the brand preaches about not being about the sale; yet that is truly what they care about—sales and customer conversion. (I mean it is a business after all). Also, tons of tedious optics, some people higher up take their jobs too seriously—comically so.

I've been working at Coursera for 6 months now.

Coursera is devoted to its mission of bringing the world's best learning experience to its learners. The weight and power of this mission resonates through the motivation that I see in my teammates and the leadership team.

The product has targeted an international audience since the beginning, and this is what makes Coursera unique. It is exhilarating to be working directly on a product that will impact millions of users outside of US borders.

Coursera gives a lot of autonomy to its staff, both with the product and for extra-curricular activities; employees can host meet ups at the office, work from home, take unlimited vacation (within reason), run sports games, and organize team outings.

Started off the job thinking I was helping people with their skin. We used fancy tools to measure the water and oil content of people's skin in order to recommend products that would help them. As someone with past skincare problems I wanted to help people gain their confidence back. However, the company is way more focused on how much you sell rather than how much you're helping the customer. We were told to push customers to buy more even if it wasn't in their budget, sell them the bigger sizes even though they hadn't even tried it yet and wouldn't know how it affected their skin. Bonuses are given out based on how much the store made over their monthly goal, which was usually extremely unrealistic. I worked there for almost 2 years and only ever got a bonus once.

Aesop is a company that has profited off marketed themselves as a socially-minded/progressive/ethical business. Aesop has previously made large internal and external statements about local and global events, yet they have been silent on the issue of Israel's attacks on Palestine. 
Customers love to shop at a trendy brand that they think aligns with their values and Aesop uses this as a marketing tool. They've made statements on The Voice to Parliament, Black Lives Matter, Invasion Day and LGBTQIA+ issues. However, these gestures are meaningless when they have connections to a country committing war crimes/genocide (Israel) and generally won't make any statements of solidarity with Palestine. This is likely because they are more concerned with profit loss than human rights.
Staff across Aesop asked senior management for more clarity about Aesop/L'Oreal's connections with, and business dealings with Israel and no explanation was given. 
No number of perks and benefits can make up for that.
+ Yes, it is like a cult. They've been known to ask certain staff members to change their accent/voice to sound more 'Aesop' - the way they hire for a culture fit is very classist. 

All in all, it's a good casual job if you are able to put these major moral dilemmas aside.
Good benefits and work life balance

Such comprehensive training that you will be able to name the products in your sleep. You get to work in a beautiful environment; no two stores are alike and each offer a pleasing sensory experience to all it's employees and patrons. The company offers a generous discount on their products and sometimes you get them for free. If you're able to land a full time gig, they offer PTO, sick days, and medical insurance (but in time, you'll realize that this hardly happens unless you become a Store Manager). The employees are generally kind and intelligent. Aesop tends to attract creative, curious, and passionate people with a flair for design/ the arts. You will definitely be working among aspiring fashion designers, thespians, singers that are trying to make it, typical Instagram 'minimalists', and so on. If you're lucky, you'll get to work with an awesome manager that is personable, understanding, and fun to work with. All in all, it's a good job if you're still a student, have your own pursuits outside of the job, or trying to get your foot in the door in the world of luxury retail.

Company is constantly restructuring and NYC base office in constant chaos. No one knows what they are doing and people are quitting and/or being terminated at a record pace. The company took away the L’Oreal Profit Share to all retail employees, while the home office staff and District Managers were able to maintain it. The benefits get less and less each year but they expect more of you and not less. Many promotions fail because of poor planning and not listening to their stores. If you are critical of the company at all and offer suggestions, you are deemed negative. They promise quick growth but constantly skip over qualified internal candidates to hire outsiders with no relevant background, who often hold the job for less than a year. Many District Managers try to micro manage your store and make your life hell. The Planning for sales plan is done so last minute and in such random ways it makes it very hard to earn the small bonus incentives they offer. It’s really ensulting after making the company a ton of money much of the time you are offered a pizza party, snacks, or extra free Kiehls products.... which you often have to fight to get and constantly remind upper management about. The HR department is a joke and will not take you seriously and many people have had to go to L’Oreal Ethics and beyond with their issues to be resolved. L’Oreal has some good perks, but I would not recommend a position at Kiehls, Especially in free standing store management.

In place of an effective business strategy, clearly communicated and supported by head office, there are silly, unreasonable, ineffective expectations at store level, usually communicated in a panicked, unprofessional and contradictory manor. High level of staff turnover, 23 managers/assistant managers left in just over 3 years. I had 5 area managers and 5 HR officers over a similar period. Also at senior management level the turnover is high, meaning GM’s never build rapport, have a clear long term strategy or duty of care, as a result they fail to deal with poor operations, cultural or structural issues during their time with the brand. They seem to spend time exclusively with 8 or so middle managers in head office, most of whom are stale. This apathy and disconnect then filters down. Under industry standard for salary (-20% in my experience) and holiday (annual leave starts at 22 days), mitigated..they say when you start, by commission. This is a cynical lie as targets are unachievable (+30-60%).  Poor work/life balance, expectations of joining several watts app groups which are over used during out of office times, used in place of professional emails by area managers who are lazy and want to avoid email trails, sometimes down right illegal when it comes to professional expectations regarding communication (requesting updated weekend business plans and strategy planning at 2.30 pm on a Friday...via watts app), all raised with HR, ignored mostly by middle managers. Few yearly appraisals held, no clear communication regarding progression, especially within brands inside L’Oréal. Lip service giving to long boarding, coaching, succession planning etc. I saw next to nothing during my time, despite the large number of spreadsheets you were asked to complete. In this respect Kiehl’s feels like it is stuck in the 80’s. Expecting unpaid over time to prove you’re worthy, no respect for work life balance, “mushroom management” approach (keep them all in the dark and they’ll grow) and the blame game when things aren’t running smoothly. There is no leadership to speak of, the working environment is quite unhealthy and morale across all stores is very low.
Nicely designed spaces to work in.

Working at Coursera was extremely challenging and unhealthy. I was so excited by the values that were written on the wall. But that's just one of the inconsistencies that exists within its walls. To say that it was toxic sounds trite and over-used. So I'll describe it by sharing some of the books I bought while I was working there: Methods of Persuasion, Crucial Conversations, Let That 'Stuff' Go, Beating the Workplace Bully, Emotional Intelligence 2.0, Have a Nice Conflict, Loser Think, and Verbal Judo. (Somehow they even weaponized The Culture Code!)

Worse still, there is rampant nepotism. The Stanford mafia is real!
Read the experience of executive staff and one level down, it will quickly become clear that many are not qualified for the positions they occupy.

There are essentially no promotions and those who are promoted receive that recognition because of relationships, not performance.

The new CEO, Jeff Maggioncalda, has run 1 company before Coursera, not a great choice for this growth company. Additionally, he laid off 15% of the company, not based on performance, even though $60M was just raised. Does he even have a heart?

The people you meet here end up being life-long friends because you already have one of the most important things in common - values.

Integrity is listed as a core value of the company but the brewing department’s management seems to have missed that part of Sierra Nevada 101. Everyone is looking to stab you in the back to advance their careers. Despite there being very little prospect for advancement. If you are well qualified for the job don’t bother applying. The quest for equity means that they can’t afford to invest in you. They don’t want brewers, just low budget operators.

- Since the re org, middle managers have resources cut to a ridiculous level, they will use the most ridiculous  reason not to give you a raise or comp adjustment like "you eat too much snacks is unprofessional" or "client find your voice irritating" and not give a raise because of it even if you had performed better than anyone on your team.
-on enterprise, leadership is more worried about their weekend plans than recognizing or leading their team, they will take credit on employees back with no shame. 
-It doesn't matter if you work harder or smarter than everyone else is, if you do not come from a top university forget about recognition, raises or bonuses. (completely against the values)
-Salaries ar not even close to be competitive, the new bonus process is a joke.
- they will promise you a raise if you deliver OKRs and deliver ambitious projects, once you deliver they will use the worst excuses to not give you the raise they promised, and take the credit for it.
-with everyone quitting they will give you more work and promise you a raise or promotion, but at the end again will not happen, all a lie so you do not leave, and if you exceed your goals, forget about recognition, they will take credit for it.
- It will be 3 years soon, i got "promoted " but no compensation raise, I still have the same salary since i started, I brought it up to my manager,  3 years same salary is unacceptable, i have successfully delivered all my our in the last 3 years, still no raise, I have completed the projects and extra projects, still no raise,  3 years same salary and i only get excuses, "the new promotion process has changed" , " with the re org i manage not to reduce your salary and have a (ridiculous) bonus for you!" ,  they will tell you the salary is more than faire, and show them that the competition is paying 30 % better, they will not even reply and change the subject. 
- a new teammate with a lower level has the same salary than you, they are unable to provide a reason. Other than "you should not have that information".
- there is 2 kind of people here: the hard worker, takes the values seriously and the lazy one that takes credit for everything and keep lying to you until you burnt out, you are replaceable anyways if not you they will find someone else they can keep working hard until they figure out they have been played or burnout, in the mean time they will take credit from you and your hard work.
-0 work life balance, "it's a start up we need to be available at any moment we have clients around the world" but management is not available to talk about raises or career development, nor vision of the org. they will only find time to take credit.

If you’re serious about design, advancing your craft and career, then beware: Indiegogo is a dead end.

Management possesses zero experience in branding, below-mediocre design competence, and enables an uninspired mindset in designers to make haste—because of poor project management—rather than positioning them to create with intentionality, polish, and efficiency. The design team thus lacks a structure for success: no vision, no design system, no pixel school and is given inept hands-on design direction. The result is clunky UX, incohesive (and comical) art direction, and poor execution of craft throughout—basically, work that’s not to be proud of. And for a critical touchpoint to IGG's brand development, its design presents a deaf ear to resonating with users for what should be a space that honors their ideas, dreams, causes, investment, and community-thinking.

The designers here are at unfortunate risk, not only handicapped from doing good work and advancing their skills but from growing their careers and earnings—their livelihoods, after all. Better days are promised, but that rhetoric is never convincing. Time is limited and being wasted; the competition will not wait for management to all of a sudden become adept at design and branding (and nor should the designers expect to continue waiting). And that possibility is pointless anyway, because strong design management is not built from giving authority and responsibility to unskilled people. So, what to do?

I joined TOMS because I wanted to have positive social impact and I thought that was the goal of the company.  Since joining I realize that money seems to be more important than mission and I'm disappointed.  

Senior leadership is going in multiple directions and comes across as more interested in hitting numbers to make their bonus then in serving people well (both through TOMS giving and to TOMS own employees).

A couple months ago they had a large layoff due to low sales.  Instead of holding senior leadership accountable, they laid-off some of the most experienced employees.  They also laid off a number of the oldest employees - the ones who sacrificed to actually build the brand and didn't come for the money.  It was at this moment where those of us left realized we could all be easily tossed aside.  Dozens of experienced people have left since then and most of the rest of us are looking.  

If you are looking for a good name to put on the resume, take a job here.  If you are looking for personal growth, there are little opportunities for growth.  If you are looking to work for a brand that makes a difference - there are so many more to look into.

- Company is partnerships driven. If partners don't wont something, its not going to happen. Coursera has essentially not innovated in the last two years because its partners don't want any change. - Poor product-market fit.
- If you don't have a Stanford degree, you won't get promoted.

This was one of the most toxic environments I had ever worked in. I was bullied by my manager, constantly criticized to the point where he made me draft emails and have him read and correct them before I was allowed to send them out. Not only was there an overall dread of losing your job because there were several layoffs and VPs and Directors constantly quitting, but there was no collaboration between teams. My manager made comments to me that were racist and sexist. I had filed a formal complaint to HR but they did not do anything about it other than let me know that my manager would undergo training. Because of this job, I had severe anxiety and depression and had to seek professional help. My self esteem declined drastically during this role due to the micro-management and toxicity and I felt that I couldn’t do anything right.

Unfortunately, there is a pervasive cultural divide between senior management and the employees. I believe the senior management was responding to pressure from the board, but the outcome was that there was constant discussion about "sustainability", which is an unnecessary euphemism for "profit". The executive management believed that the employees wouldn't tolerate working on things that would make edX make money. I don't know if that was true about anyone (it wasn't true about me), but the real problem is how they dealt with it: they *lied*.

edX's mission is to "increase access to high-quality education for everyone, everywhere", but employees at edX aren't allowed to work on projects that would increase access for people that have slow or unreliable internet connections. We were constantly pushed to work on projects at the behest of large corporate or government donors.

At the same time, the employees aren't valued and the organization is inefficient and misdirected. When employees reported dissatisfaction with their jobs in a review last year, the management responded in an unbelievably corporate way: they created a committee.

The committee reported its findings to Wendy Cebula (the COO and President). When she was told that employees felt that employee retention was not a priority to executive management she said, "they're right. When someone leaves edX, I see it as an opportunity to get an A-player in here."

The tragedy is that many of edX's employees are talented people who really do care about the stated mission and have made personal sacrifices to be there. My sincerest wish is that the organization is put under more sincere management and edX can have the impact that we hope for.

If you (as edX's president) feel that you have to hit some deadline for a donor, how about just saying that instead of couching it in a fantasy about helping the world by starting with the people that (frankly) don't really need the help?

Oh man. We've had some changes that have been tough lately. We had a reorg last last year, that although it was the right thing to do, but it left a lasting effect on the culture of the company. Having been through this at a previous startup, it takes a while to move on past this, but I am optimistic we'll be able to move on and be even better and more profitable than before. 

One of our core company values is deep honestly. So, with deep honesty I'll say, we had an awful performance cycle at the beginning of the year.  Fortunately, people acknowledge this, we've been able to talk about this openly, and management is in the process of fixing it. 

This is the reason I give Coursera 5 stars. It's the willingness to admit mistakes and learn from them that I respect the most.

A few years ago, I asked myself whether I would regret later if I joined Coursera, and the answer was "No!". So I joined. A few years later, I moved on, and here is the review of the company: 

There were happy and tough times, wins and loses, just like any other startups in Bay area. As a career seeker, the main problem you need to figure out is what you want to develop in the next few years. If Coursera provides something you really want to develop or gain experience on, you should give it a try. If it doesn't provide the environment and/or opportunity, to leave without a grudge is always an option.

1) One of the best education companies which can change the world and impact lots of people.

2) Many opportunities if you really believe online learning will be the future of learning. 

3) Interesting problems to address, including both technical and non-technical issues across multiple domains including business, education, technology, etc.

4) Many talented people are still at Coursera and I would recommend everyone to work with them.
Good product bonus, fellow staff members are generally good.

Also, this is an edited version of the original review. Of course Indiegogo had it flagged and then immediately asked someone to write a positive review to bury this. Another example of shady and political moves vs focusing on fixing the business.

**second time Indiegogo has had this flagged for editing. So hiding the truth seems to be a full time job now.

Well here it is again, edited to meet Glassdoors community guidelines ;)

With the pros out of the way, we can get started on the issues that make Indiegogo a worrisome place to work, especially if you've been misinformed about the financial situation, cash flow, burn rates, stock value, and even the decision-making process of upper management.

Overall management and leadership is lacking, unethical and more closely resembles an entourage of old friends and colleagues who have nowhere else to go.

The whole company is lacking the properly experienced management and general direction of a organization thats going to survive their limited runway. Sales goals and quotas are created to simply pressure the teams into keeping things afloat. It seems more and more that revenue focused groups in the company are taking credit for any and every campaign that brings in any kind of money. 

The entire organization is floundering to survive in an ever shrinking crowdfunding market. Funding is drying up and its doubtful that any investor is willing to sink any more money into an org that hasnt been profitable in almost 10 years. 

How can Indiegogo properly project growth, revenue, and devise a strategy when the financial and overall business data is simply wrong. This is just a matter of bad work by inexperienced leaders hired by inexperienced leaders. A players don't hire B players...B players hire C players. Is that the saying? 

With the recent state of affairs in Silicon Valley and the emphasis on how an organization protects its leaders from their own incompetence, this is important to note. What ever function hired to do so, is the same that finds way to bring in friends, fire experts and ultimately erase glassdoor reviews. 

Have anyone mentioned the reviewer witch hunts that happened not 6 months ago when management spent time questioning employees about negative reviews?

The way the company operates is exactly what most people in silicon valley have been complaining about. Certain functions in the company act as the smiling faces and carefully chosen words that stand between upper management and responsibility. If someone at the top wants to fire someone because the expert didn't agree with their strategy, an internal team will come up with some BS excuse. 

The fact of the matter is that the leaders at Indiegogo have probably spent more time telling "alt facts" than most. But then again, those "alt facts" are really there to protect inexperienced managers and pressured execs to find scape-goats for overall company performance.

It's no wonder the company is not only bleeding money, it's bleeding employees. The attrition rate is worse than any company I've experienced in Silicon Valley.

Employees are demoralized, bored, and simply tired of under performing quarter over quarter. Management continues to lead the company in singing Kumbaya, while someone else tries to avert eyes from the data that matters. As much as I prefer not to quote Trump, this is a fitting circumstance.

"It's fake news...very fake news"

I honestly don't even know where to start. I don't say things like this lightly, but this is an amazing company filled with, by far, the best people I have ever had the privilege to work with. Prior to Coursera, I worked for a few startups of various sizes and stages and one large, well-known company. Those companies could only have dreamed of having a group of people as smart, driven, articulate, talented, collaborative, and happy as the people at Coursera. 

A few things:

— They are creating career paths for those on the technical side. I have never seen so much effort, especially at a company of this size, put towards creating ways for employees to grow.

— Cross-functional collaboration is HUGE and you can easily get access anyone in the company you need to talk to.

— If you have an idea, some guts, and a good case, it's possible to make a big impact.

— Minor in the grand scheme, but lunch and dinner are excellent. Also, we have no meeting Wednesday and many people work from home.

— I can't speak for anyone else, but I'm very happy with compensation and benefits. 

— A+++++ work/life balance. I was shocked to find out people actually use their unlimited vacation.

— In my experience, everyone I have encountered in management, including C-levels, are approachable and smart, yet humble. There's no ego here. 

I decided to post after I saw some previous reviews (that look like they were written by the same person). I don't doubt that person had a less than positive experience, but that is not even remotely close to the company I know.
Chill during the week. Busy on weekends.

When I agreed to sign an NDA as part of a severance package instead of taking legal action, I thought I was an outlier. 

Since then, it's come to my attention that Kiehl's regularly uses non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) to silence employees who may have legal grounds to file ethical complaints or law suits. 

I realize now that L'Oreal USA and Kiehl's  regularly have people in their human resources department make retaliatory threats and  pressure employees to sign NDAs as a  way to silence potential whistle-blowers.
This company is filled with smart, dedicated, and nice people.  They care about the cause of the company, and they care about fellow employees.

- Mission: You are genuinely changing people's lives for the better everyday by working on this product 
- Peers: Supportive and trusting culture amongst peers. Of course people might have different opinions on tactics and ideas, but we all want what is best for our learners and partners education institutions, so we trust each others' motivations. Everyone is incredibly impressive and accomplished; I'm proud and honored to work amongst these bright folks. 
- Leadership: Leadership is inspired and inspiring. Also, I actually *like* them all as people; they are all *good* people. (No evil jerks like I've seen before at other startups.) I think they all complement each other well. I enjoy our weekly All Hands meeting where we can ask them any question we want and they have to answer. 
- Office Environment: Clean, large office with plenty of meeting spaces. Fun work environment with lots of creative Coursera-related decor. Lunch, dinner, snacks provided. Gym on site. Lots of fun activities like Monday Beer Club, Wednesday Supper Club, Friday Happy Hour, Talent Shows, office garden, Food Truck Thursdays, karaoke, "Show and Tell" Mondays (where people can give 5 min presos on something Coursera related or something totally random and cool), Tech Talk Tuesdays, international candy wall, etc.  
- Salary structure is what I find ideal: They hire people they expect that, in another organization, would receive their performance-based bonus every quarter on top of a base salary. Therefore you earn an annual salary that is reflective of a competitive "base", and then they add on what you might get from another organization as your performance-based bonus as your *total salary*. No performance-based bonuses; you get money no matter what as part of a *larger salary*. I think this makes the work culture have less pressure to fit goals made in the beginning of the quarter that always end up changing anyway! Hitting your goals is about personal fulfillment, supporting your team, and supporting the learners. If you aren't a top performer, you are letting more people down than yourself. 
- Product: Exciting product moves to the "on-demand" and more flexible style of learning for courses. Only edtech company with an Android app.  
- PR/Press/Marketing: Overall the press likes us and is supportive of our mission. We're still a "hot" startup, but there's recognized long-term potential from the media. It is easy to market a product one really believes in. 
- Community: Users (i.e., learners) love us and appreciate us, and they are vocal about letting us know this everyday. 
- Time-off: Unlimited PTO–FOR REAL. I've worked in offices with "Unlimited PTO" and they made me feel guilty every time I took off. Here managers encourage people to take the time they need, and people really use it as they need it. 
- WFH: They are also pretty friendly about letting people WFH on Wednesdays (during "No Meeting Wednesdays") and are flexible in letting you work within the hours that fit your working style best (all dependent on your teams and projects, as expected.)
Lots of pressure from above, often unrealistic.
diverse group of mostly nice/fun employees, work-life balance possible, exciting mission statement and great office location.
no bad experience while working as part timer

- edX is incredibly slow and bureaucratic for a small company. Every decision, including small ones, require layers of approvals before moving forward. This contributes to a terrible meeting culture where most of the company spends their days in pointless meetings vs executing. 
- edX will be a business school case study some day of a great idea and opportunity that went horribly awry. Don't let the headlines of the recent acquisition fool you. This was a fire sale. There was no path to financial sustainability. The acquisition was a necessary outcome for us to try and survive in the long-term. This was NOT the result of a successful, growing business. Our growth has been anemic across nearly every product line. We're constantly told and selling to partners that the next big thing is what is going to turn things around for us and them. We've finally reached a point where we've run out of rope after failures of Masters, MicroMasters, MicroBachelors, and many (many) more.
- No focus. We are constantly looking over our shoulder at what Coursera is doing and adapting our strategy to follow suit. Coursera is out executing us at every level, and with their recent IPO, will continue to widen the gap. They are easily 3-5 years ahead of us on product strategy, marketing, etc. Many of our partners have or are currently disengaging with edX to focus more of their energy on working with Coursera because of the ROI that they provide and the more advanced tools and features that have been built in the last couple of years. We have always been chasing the "shiny object" instead of focusing on our customers and executing on their behalf. Most of the tools that our partners (or learners) use haven't been improved or changed in years no matter how many times partners ask about it. They are finally fed up with it and many are taking their business elsewhere.

It has been an amazing ride ever since the first day I stepped into HQ.
From an almost week-long orientation process where we are immersed in the TOMS culture, to the giving trips where we get to complete the full circle in TOMS' "One for One," it is a completely unique and gratifying experience that very few get to experience.  While it is true that employees are treated to all-you-can-drink latte's, on-campus happy hours, yearly company retreats, and amazing benefits, we are all expected to perform and place it all on the line day after day.

TOMS is still very much a movement and like any ripple in the water, the movement is continuing to grow. My coworker and I ask each other all the time if we've ever had those days where we really don't want to show up to work.  I'll write back here once the answer ever becomes 'Yes.'

The company is still growing and finding ways to remain sustainable. As a US company where most of the employees and business is centralized in the US, they still see themselves as the center of the world and want to expand worldwide and grow in other markets by applying the same methodology that works in the US. This is very common in US companies though and it's not the first time that I've seen a US company fail when trying to go international.

It's still early for edX though. Over the next year or so we'll see if they realize they need to adapt to the markets where they try to grow, or continue expecting those markets to change and be more US-like.

A common practice at TOMS is for new managers to push out existing workers and build out a new team. Like other reviews have stated, the new group of managers are poor culture fit at TOMS.  Individually, these managers are pretty useless and insecure. They establish relevance by pushing out old employees and gather support by hiring new ones.  This is a top-down approach that was executed at the highest level at TOMS. When the President was hired two years ago, he immediately hired a team of C-Level executives to report to him. Then each of these execs hired their own sets of VPs and then Directors and so forth. None of these positions were promoted from within TOMS.

This self-serving management tarnished the managers/employees relationship beyond the professional level.  As a result, gossip and clashes were formed and company became divided.  It deteriorated workers efficiency, core value and morale, which eventually impacted sales. I don't think TOMS can turn this around. 

Sure these things happen in all companies. But TOMS should have been the exception because it was built on employees values and working together for a cause. However, the employees who help built TOMS are all gone because of poor management. The real losers are the children/adults in need of TOMS giving shoes and eye treatments. At this rate, TOMS won't be able to provide to anyone but the greedy managers.

Overall, I don't think these problems are unique to Kickstarter.

Cruelty and short-sightedness: The layoff in Nov 2022 was handled very badly. Many long-time employees were dismissed overnight, with lots of knowledge gone with them, together with some cultural aspects that used to make Coursera a good place to work for. 

Shadiness: Coursera refuses to publish the exact number or percentage of the layoff, while many other companies do at the moment of layoff. 

Sneakiness: What's even worse than that, I (joined less than 1 year ago) was dismissed by Coursera due to "performance issues" right after the global layoff, although the manager used to give me pretty positive feedback before the layoff, and I was offered a tiny (less than 3 weeks) severance package, which I refused. In comparison, these laid-off employees got around 4 months of severance pay or more. By framing it as "dismissal" rather than "layoff", I think Coursera tries to circumvent government scrutiny and get away with paying less severance. And I believe I'm not alone. 

This shady business practice must be made known and punished. 

The severance they offered has violated the laws of my local jurisdiction and I am pursuing legal action against them. I was vigilant enough to keep some compelling evidence before termination. If you are also an ex-Courserian and want to sue Coursera, we can initiate a class action, though unfortunately I'm not allowed to share contact info on Glassdoor. I have posted it on Reddit, you can find it by googling.

This layoff is actually not the first time. When Jeff M. stepped up as the CEO in 2017, he laid off 40+ employees, many of whom contributed significantly to a round of funding they raised at that time. People might have forgotten, but in 2022, Jeff reminds us again of this. 

The company is no longer working on its real mission. It's now just pleasing the shareholders on the capital market. This layoff and the relevant shady, illegal practices make me seriously doubt the prospect of the company. 

My suggestion to current employees: keep evidence, especially related to your performance, even when things seem to be pretty good. And form a Slack group outside the company's control so that it becomes easier for you to initiate a class action, especially in situations like mine.
Organised, professional, kind and true to themselves.

It's unfortunate to see a company invest so much in "culture" and workplace aesthetics, but lack the foresight to see the void of employee growth and career pathing. Toms grew too fast and had no one to steer the ship. The talented executive team the once managed Toms was either let go due to direction change (owner wanting to expand his role and manage their department) or left. The company spoke of the Toms family and being part of the movement but at it's core was only concerned about profits and rapid continued growth. It's unfortunate to see such frustration at every level of a company from the executive team down to lower management. Toms is full of rumors and is built on a hierarchy of management that directs their team out of fear or personal goals. Internal rumors flare continually and talks of people being let go or quitting are a common occurrence. Employee turnover is always a clear indication of the performance of a company - and over the last 5 years the revolving door of Toms has seen almost an entire workforce come and go.

- Insanely lengthy processes that mimic Microsoft-level org structures when Coursera is really a start-up. Little work gets done efficiently. 
- Lack of trust and micro-management. 
- Everyone wants to have a say in how things get done, which leads to mediocre at best results (surprise!) 
- "Long-term Vision", but short-term decision making. If something does not have immediate impact, it gets tossed aside. There is no strategic or practical go-to-market, it just exists on a google slide deck. 
- The leadership at Coursera is very weak. Most just look out for themselves, have no voice, don't push back, and agree to everything to keep their manager happy 
- The biggest red flag: 10%+ of the workforce was laid off before Christmas. Not longer after the layoffs, 'president club' was announced for the first time. Seems like the leadership team has mislaid their moral compass a little bit here. Also makes you wonder how critical those layoffs were, and how much of it is just taking advantage of the current tech hell we're living in.

You have to upsell a lot for the waffle cones, and they give you a talk if you weren't selling enough of them that week. It can be pretty annoying. They are very selective when it comes to applicants, but it's an ice cream shop. They treat working there like it's a bigger deal than it really should be. They were low on workers but had a stack of applications in the back office that they didn't even look at, which was infuriating because they would call me to work on days that I said I can't work. Also the people they would hire were terrible workers so they aren't as selective as they think they are. I was asked to work while I'm in class on multiple occasions because they were low on employees.  Once they brought in this woman who quit about 5 years prior because they had no one else. Even after I quit, my former boss was still calling me asking for me to work. I had to block his number.  They also try to cut corners when it comes to costs. The register is slow and outdated, the fridge sometimes has issues.  Among a great deal of other things that needs to be fixed in the store, they refused to fix it because they were low on money. The boss insisted on trying to fix everything himself.  
They were very shady about paying the managers what they were really owed (which really wasn't much only a dollar more than the other cashiers). They did a ton more work for barely any more pay, and they had to come in more for weeks of training.

Anyone can message anyone thanks to Slack and there's a real sense of community. Head office make some strange and non-sensical decisions

1. Understaff issues: 
Understaff in the whole NY area, afraid to take sick leave because literally no one can cover for you. You feel bad for your coworker who is working with you that day. The hiring process is very lengthy, which helps HR find the most "Aesop aligned" person, but it also works against the company by taking too long to find proper support for staff that is already overworked and tired.

2. No room for growth, even harder if you were interested in another department:
I have seen too many talented people left the company (who were tenure and passion with strong KPI's). If you studied a major and had career goal within another department it is impossible for you to transfer, reason being you don't have experience, experiences you can't learn while you're in the store.... Aesop HQ love to  hire externally, including positions that made sense to hire internally (Store managers, Visual Merchandising positions) Retail consultants are there to train a new manager while acting like one and getting hourly pay. 

3. Store budget issues:
Most stores operate with mainly PT staffs, the excuse is that the budget for stores is not high enough to have more than one FT consultant and a store manager. Some stores have a  budget for "Senior Retail Consultant" (essentially, Assistant Store Manager)  but depending on how busy the store is, that may not be enough coverage on the floor. FT employees only get health benefits and not PTO, while senior retail consultants gets both. 

4. Responsibilities / Compensation: 
This is not the kind of job where you can just show up and clock in. There are a lot of small tasks you are required to complete even for a PT consultant, which can change if you work at a busier store that has no manager (which happens often). Upper management will say you're not responsible for certain tasks, but you may find yourself doing them anyway because if not the store won't be operating properly (responding to head office emails, ordering product, communicating with other stores for transfers, all this on top of actually selling and working the sales floor.) 

5. Hourly Rate: 
With the increase of minimum wage in NY area, the salary is not competitive enough. it used to be $5 dollars higher, and now it's $3 dollars higher and compared with the amount of work you do, it's not enough.

Indiegogo is truly a mission-driven company.

Though we are incredibly busy with the day to day operations of the company, people do not lose sight of our larger purpose: to increase access to capital, to democratize finance, and empower people to fund their passions.

Indiegogo also extends this empowerment to its employees. Even as an entry level analyst, I have been encouraged to pursue projects that I am interested in and have felt that I can impact the organization in a meaningful way. There is no shortage of work to be done so the team recognizes that strict hierarchy and red-tape impede progress. 

I have found myself working with some of the smartest and most friendly people I have ever met. Everyone is approachable and eager to see you succeed.  The more experienced employees will take time out of their busy schedule in order to meet with you and help you plan your career, provide advice and resources, or just to chat to get to know you. 

In summary, not only do you get to create meaningful change, you get to have fun while doing it with awesome people!

-TOMS lost the fastball years ago and kept making the same mistakes over and over again rather than innovating. As the brand lost its place in the zeitgeist (and more important, the market) employees were tasked with more and more with fewer and fewer resources (financial or personnel). As a result the output became more stale and repetitive and left people burned out and uninspired, further depressing the brand image. These mistakes were compounded by spending money outside the company on terrible marketing campaigns rather than investing in the people and ideas within the building. Basically it was a pretty unfortunate (and avoidable) downward loop.

Major imbalance in M/F representation on executive team. Executive meetings are basically bro-fests. Pay is not as competitive as other startups. Inexperienced leadership. Really top heavy. Promotions and title inflation are used as retention strategy which can of course be a plus if you're the person being promoted. On the other hand if you're the subordinate, you now have an inexperienced manager who probably has their own inexperienced manager. Blind leading the blind. Another side effect of this is that people leave after a short period of time because they leverage their new title for better pay somewhere else. They have old inefficient systems in place but are reluctant to break them down and start fresh and keep building on top of them instead. Too many short sighted decisions and experiments which they play off as pivoting and say "we're so nimble" instead of trying to learn from the mistake. People get hired specifically for these new ideas and then get fired when the project goes sour.

Before you take a job here ask your interviewer about the current team and then ask what it looked like 3 months ago. Ask why your position is open. A lot of people have been fired quietly or have left willingly over the past year. They ask you to write a Glassdoor review your first week so of course there are a lot of five star reviews.

Since Bain has come into the picture the majority of C level and VP executives are no longer at the company. In some cases these positions have already turned over twice in three years. There have been a lot of layoffs over the past few years. Employees have been let go no matter what they've done or how long they've been employed. Women have been let go immediately upon returning from maternity leave. Quality people have been let go and jobs have been outsourced to more affordable countries. These are normal occurrences in corporate America but TOMS was supposed to be better than this. Was TOMS ever really better than the rest of corporate America? Treating employees poorly is not something that started when Bain came into the picture. Many years ago, at the peak of TOMS success people were still making an unlivable wage in LA. When the founder was approached and asked to pay people a little more so his employees could afford to live he said if you don't want to work here for what we're paying you then you can go work somewhere else. There are plenty of other people that want to work here. All employees were treated as though working at TOMS was some sort of privilege. With all that has been happening, the authenticity of why the company was started has been put into question. Was TOMS really started to make a difference in children's lives or just a social platform that was used to make a lot of money?
The culture has suffered dramatically with all the changes that have taken place over the past few years. Co-workers used to be like a family and now everyone just seems so sad to be here all the time. For most of us, coming to the office every day was something we used to look forward to, now it's dreaded. 
The brand name has been tarnished by selling so much product in stores like Ross. Once you saturate the market with $20 shoes people aren't going to pay $50 for them. There has been irreparable damage done to the brand. Consumers dont value it as highly and it will take a lot of work to turn it around. And it will take work, it's not going to happen just because it's TOMS.

- Startup growing pains and figuring out how to best keep everyone in the loop on accomplishments and future plans for each team, particularly with new leadership. This is getting better as we stabilize team structures.  
- Product Team is either extremely junior or extremely senior, but we are currently hiring to fill the gap. 
- It's in Mountain View... waaah waaahhhh... but it's only a 15 walk from the Mountain View Caltrain station. 
- Although we are the leading edtech website, we're still figuring out the ideal monetization strategies for long-term profitability. But this is getting better and we have teams dedicated to figuring it out. Not too concerned right now as we have funding.

While we’ve built up senior management a lot over the past year, in general, everyone is still figuring out how to work effectively in a larger company. Things can be chaotic, and I think people who have been here a long time take certain types of communication for granted—it’s much harder to keep 85 people informed than 15. Everyone has great intentions, but sometimes execution is lacking.

If you are willing to make your own way, you can accomplish a lot here. If you’re looking for someone to teach you how to do your job, you’ll probably be unhappy.
Our smaller teams require greater hustle from everyone, but that simply gives each team member more opportunity to shine.

Pay was far too low, but not the worst I've seen in retail. Things changed on a dime, company layoffs, quick marketing changes with little to no notice/no materials or support for it. Major lack in labor support as well: high amount of freight with no hours to get it done, reprimanded for being off the floor or overusing labor to get it all done, often falling behind timelines and floorset execution because of that with no empathy or understanding from upper management. High expectation selling culture with low or no incentive (no commission, but top performers got better discounts). Vans was/is suffering financially and made a lot of cuts to things that are crucial for store teams to flourish: technology, leadership conference opportunity, labor again.

The longer I’m with Aesop and the more senior I become, the more I see that many of the values that the company boasts are a hollow facade. There’s no doubt that my team and my peers are the sole reason I remain. Senior Management are obsessive and micro-managerial when it comes to revenue and you’ll fall out of favor very quickly when you stop delivering sales for any period of time. Often times, targets feel unachievable and you’ll struggle to reach out or admit to needing support as your worth is directly tied to your productivity. Don’t even get me started on the impossibility of growth if you’re not in the right city - it’s cruel to ask an employee to uproot their family to move as their only option to progress.

I've witnessed many great freelancers being led on with the hopes of becoming full-time, after putting at least a full year of hard work, blood, sweat, and tears, and in the meantime, many newcomers are being hired without even a hint of a probationary period. In addition, employees had been terminated with as little as a day's notice. I've also heard the words, "Avoid walking in the main entrance when you interview. The girl you'll be replacing will know you're interviewing for her position if she sees you." 
People have been leaving left and right. Certain new department leaders were clueless regarding their job descriptions, and are taking advantage of their new teams. It's a mess.

I personally had a great experience while at TOMS but mainly because I really loved my team. It was having to work with other departments that was the main problem. Lack of accountability runs rampant and it's incredibly difficult to do your job when other people expect you to do it for them. There is also a huge lack of processes which drives me insane... it still feels like a start-up in that sense. Prior to my leaving there were quite a few lay-offs. It was definitely necessary to eliminate some positions but it seems as though they got rid of some of the most dedicated and smartest people. Bad mistake. By the time I left, morale was at an all-time low. I have never felt so much palpable anxiety at any company I've ever been at - and I've been at some pretty down and out places before.
can get "clique-ish" on the inside

In the past month, I’ve seen 6 coworkers break down in tears due to overwork and physical fatigue. 
That’s right. Grown men and women. Crying. At work. For an education company.
Coursera is a company in growth mode; hard work and stress should be expected. Where it gets weird is how employees are pressured to exude high levels of positivity, “wokeness”and inspiration while working long hours into the night, fighting for more help, and having their work criticized in public under the toxic mantra of “learn, change, grow”.
If you were to sit down and talk with any employee in private they would admit that they flat out hate their job and are actively looking for a new one. 

So why aren’t there more bad Glassdoor reviews you ask? It’s because most employees have stock allocations and don’t want to post anything negative publicly that affect the perception/value of Coursera.

Management is very corrupt. They work out deals to help themselves gain notoriety and "fame". I am not proud to work for the management team as I have heard them use the one for one give as a ploy to get discounts on services, which would be fine if we were a non-profit business, however, TOMS is a for profit company. The day I overheard this was the day my view slightly shifted and allowed me to see the corruption. If any employee takes a step back and looks at the management team around or very close to them they will see patterns of corruption that go so deep. Employees are reviewed every 6 months, yet in the time I have been there, not once has anyone asked how I fell my manager is performing, or what it is that my manager can do to help me perform. If lead by example was taken serious this company would not exist. There are some good managers out there that try to make changes and do well for the company as a whole but more often than not they fall into the same corruption as the other managers in order to comply with the status-quo.

There are multiple layers of corrupt managers that work together to protect each other from the C-level threats. Unfortunately the C-levels are only knowing of what is being fed to them, which is a completely augmented truth. With the layers of management getting seemingly thicker and thicker it leaves little to no room for employees to get decent promotions or raises even if it be for cost of living increase. It appears that a majority of the desirable employees are leaving to go to places that they can actually grow and get paid fair wages. 

HR is another area that has major issues, as people slowly lose their names and become numbers HR is thriving and seems energized. Interaction with HR is a big risk as there is retaliation that happens all of the time. HR not only has an open door policy, but an open mouth policy when it comes to private information. Confidentiality is actually “can’t wait to tell my friend this story”. 

The culture and overall pulse of the company is so bad that a few years back they had to implement “culture captains”. They are basically bodies that HR has available to throw under the bus when things go awry. When I ask my captain what’s going on, they have some generic update that is fed to them and is obviously HR trying to use a familiar face to push off their ideas onto us.

In my pros I mentioned that the people I work WITH are a pleasure to work with, which is because the people that I work FOR are horrible people that I would expect to be slum lords or corrupt politicians. I recently saw a post about being a leader versus being a boss. If you want to work for a boss who only cares about themselves and you can deal with that and also deal with the fact that you know what you know today and just boarded the Titanic, please feel free to apply for my position when I leave.

Small but mighty, TOMS has an amazing team. It's truly impressive to see how much can be accomplished by a targeted group of passionate people who truly want to improve lives through business. Outside of the adorable puppies, slides, ping pong tables at HQ, this is a business that truly balances the work hard/play hard mentality. TOMS ensures everyone is here for the same reason, even offering "Giving Trips" to employees, placing true meaning behind the work we do every day. Simply put, I’m proud to work at TOMS.

Some of the leads (Sierra Nevada full-time employees wearing blue shirts) were very unprofessional. They made several inappropriate remarks about the customers during the working hour and was rude to the part time workers.
